dc:description:
Executive Summary DNAH7:

DNAH7, Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia 50 (MONDO:0957252), autosomal recessive

DNAH7 was first described as a Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (PCD)-causing gene in 2022 (Gao et al. 2022, PMID: 35543642). The specific disease entity, Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia 50 (MONDO:0957252), (OMIM:610061), is one of at least 45 different primary ciliary dyskinesias distinguished by a single monogenic cause. Some of the most common patient phenotypes are: Absent inner dynein arms, Chronic sinusitis and Chronic bronchitis. 

Seven variants: (2 types of genetic mutations: Frameshift (2) and Missense (5) that have been reported in 5 probands in 3 publications (PMIDs: 35543642, PMID: 34476482 and PMID: 37998386) are included in this curation.

Many of the family members of the probands were similarly genotyped and found to be heterozygous carriers. However, the phenotypic and affected status of those individuals were unknown. 

Overall, the mechanism of pathogenicity appears to be loss of function as shown by the suspected disease-causing variants in the probands. 

This gene-disease relationship is also supported by multiple forms of experimental evidence such as Expression A (Quantity: 1), Expression B (Quantity: 1) and Biochemical Function A (Quantity: 1). First, GTex data showed that DNAH6 is primarily expressed in fallopian tubes and lungs, which is consistent with PCD phenotypes (PMID: 23715323). Next, Zhang et al. 2002 demonstrated and recapitulated a phenotype that recurred in probands (PMID: 11877439). In Figure 2, cilia collected via nasal scrape from a control (A) and the PCD patient (B and C) were evaluated with electron microscopy. Both inner and outer dynein arms were observed in the cilia of the control. However, when the cilia of the PCD patient was examined, it was found that there was a near complete absence of inner arm structures. Wilken et al. 2024 found that DNAH7 is a component of the inner dynein arm of ciliary axonemes and CCDC39 localizes to ciliary axonemes and is essential for assembly of inner dynein arms and the dynein regulatory complex. DNAH7 and CCDC39 are both IDA components and are localized to the same region. Within the healthy control subjects, DNAH7 is localized throughout the entire length of ciliary axonemes (Figure 6B). However, it was found that in PCD individuals who had disease-causing variants in either CCDC39 or CCDC40 (Figure 6C,D), DNAH7 was absent from the ciliary axoneme. CCDC39 was classified as having a “definitive” relationship with PCD 14 by the Motile Ciliopathy GCEP. Refer to the curation for further details.

In conclusion, DNAH7 has a limited association with Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia 50. This classification has been clearly demonstrated and confirmed through both experimental and genetic evidence and has been upheld over time. 

This classification was approved by the Motile Ciliopathy GCEP on February 13th, 2025 (SOP Version 10).

evidence.dc:description: Abnormal ciliary motility in the model recapitulates what is seen in human probands.
evidence.rdfs:label: Wilken et al. 2024

evidence.dc:description: PMID: 23715323. Variant was expressed fallopian tubes, lungs, and testis.
evidence.rdfs:label: Genet 2015

evidence.dc:description: PCD individuals carrying disease-causing variants in either CCDC39 or CCDC40 (Figure 6C,D) showed the absence of DNAH7 from the ciliary axoneme.
evidence.rdfs:label: Wilken et al. 2024

evidence.dc:description: Functional Evidence: This staining result demonstrated that DNAH7 localized along the sperm flagella in the control subjects, whereas the DNAH7 signal was significantly decreased in the sperm flagella of the patients (Fig. 4). This was further confirmed by the result of western blot analysis performed using the spermatozoa from the DNAH7-mutant patients (Supplementary Fig. S3).

Functional Evidence: This staining result demonstrated that DNAH7 localized along the sperm flagella in the control subjects, whereas the DNAH7 signal was significantly decreased in the sperm flagella of the patients (Fig. 4). This was further confirmed by the result of western blot analysis performed using the spermatozoa from the DNAH7-mutant patients (Supplementary Fig. S3).

evidence.rdfs:label: P3
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
The Chinese proband presented with PCD-associated symptoms but was diagnosed with idiopathic asthenozoospermia.

Clinical examinations were performed on the patients with bi-allelic mutations in DNAH7 and found that they presented with normal physical development and reproductive hormone levels. Moreover, they had normal external genitalia and bilateral testicles and showed no defects in the bilateral spermatic veins.

These patients also presented with PCD-like symptoms, including chronic sinusitis and bronchitis, which suggests that they may be potential PCD sufferers.

The results from immunofluorescent staining demonstrated that DNAH7 localized along the sperm flagella in the control subjects, whereas the DNAH7 signal was significantly decreased in the sperm flagella of the patients (Fig. 4). This was further confirmed by the result of western blot analysis performed using the spermatozoa from the DNAH7-mutant patients (Supplementary Fig. S3).

evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
The Chinese proband presented with PCD-associated symptoms but was diagnosed with idiopathic asthenozoospermia.

Clinical examinations were performed on the patients with bi-allelic mutations in DNAH7 and found that they presented with normal physical development and reproductive hormone levels. Moreover, they had normal external genitalia and bilateral testicles and showed no defects in the bilateral spermatic veins.

These patients also presented with PCD-like symptoms, including chronic sinusitis and bronchitis, which suggests that they may be potential PCD sufferers.

The results from immunofluorescent staining demonstrated that DNAH7 localized along the sperm flagella in the control subjects, whereas the DNAH7 signal was significantly decreased in the sperm flagella of the patients (Fig. 4). This was further confirmed by the result of western blot analysis performed using the spermatozoa from the DNAH7-mutant patients (Supplementary Fig. S3).

Man originated from Turkey. He came from a consanguineous family.

112 Nasal NO (nL/min) and 32 ppFEV1.

Proband had sinus solitus. Proband was noted to have early onset of chronic wet cough and chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps, parental consanguinity, and P. aeruginosa infection. Normal ODA and IDA. Proband was also noted to have chronic upper airway disease and chronic wet cough, but normal nNO levels.

The proband was diagnosed as having "Possible PCD". He was also noted to have had computed tomography-confirmed bronchiectasis.

evidence.dc:description:
Functional Evidence: Immunofluorescent staining was performed on sperm samples from the patient and a fertile control man. The staining results revealed that DNAH7 in the sample from the control was observed along the whole sperm flagella and was concentrated at the mid-piece, whereas DNAH7 signal significantly decreased or was even completely absent in the sperm from the investigated patient (Figure 2A).

TEM analyses were also used to explore ultrastructural defects in the sperm of the patient. Cross-sections of sperm sample from the patient displayed major defects with severe inner dynein arms (IDAs) loss when compared to typical ‘9 + 2’ axonemal structure of the control sperm. To explore the defective mid-piece of DNAH7-deficient sperm flagella, the samples were stained with TOMM20 to label the mitochondria. As shown in Figure 2B, the DNAH7 loss disrupted the normal arrangement of mitochondria, which presented a shorter and thickened mid-piece. Specifically, cross-and longitudinal sections of the sperm mid-piece region from the patient displayed a noticeably thickened mitochondrial layer dissociated from the axoneme (Figure 2C).

evidence.rdfs:label: IV-1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Han Chinese infertile man from a consanguineous family.

This patient was regarded as the first natural human DNAH7 mutant model.

The chromosomal karyotype was 46, XY, and no Y chromosome microdeletions were reported. Semen analysis revealed typical MMAF phenotypes (especially shortened or coiled flagella).

evidence.dc:description: Downscored because experts were unconvinced by variant frequency.

Functional Evidence: This staining result demonstrated that DNAH7 localized along the sperm flagella in the control subjects, whereas the DNAH7 signal was significantly decreased in the sperm flagella of the patients (Fig. 4). This was further confirmed by the result of western blot analysis performed using the spermatozoa from the DNAH7-mutant patients (Supplementary Fig. S3).

The Chinese proband presented with PCD-associated symptoms but was diagnosed with idiopathic asthenozoospermia.

Clinical examinations were performed on the patients with bi-allelic mutations in DNAH7 and found that they presented with normal physical development and reproductive hormone levels. Moreover, they had normal external genitalia and bilateral testicles and showed no defects in the bilateral spermatic veins.

These patients also presented with PCD-like symptoms, including chronic sinusitis and bronchitis, which suggests that they may be potential PCD sufferers.

The results from immunofluorescent staining demonstrated that DNAH7 localized along the sperm flagella in the control subjects, whereas the DNAH7 signal was significantly decreased in the sperm flagella of the patients (Fig. 4).
